item.title: Indiana Jones and the Great Circle PS5 Release Date Revealed
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/indiana-jones-and-the-great-circle-ps5-release-date

Bethesda and MachineGames have announced the Indiana Jones and the Great Circle PS5 release date, with the legendary adventurer's latest jaunt coming to Sony's console next month.

As revealed in a post on the official PlayStation X account, Indiana Jones and the Great Circle launches for PS5 on April 17th. The game is already available for PC and Xbox Series X|S.

We're not yet sure whether the PS5 version of Great Circle will feature any kind of DualSense haptic support, but given that the PS5 version of racer Forza Horizon 5 does boast some nice DualSense haptics, it wouldn't be unreasonable to expect something similar from MachineGames' latest.

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is the latest in a string of Xbox games to get a PlayStation release. The first three - namely Pentiment, Grounded, and Sea of Thieves - were announced for PlayStation back in February last year.

Following that, it was revealed that Forza Horizon 5 would be coming to PlayStation, and rumors currently abound that the Gears of War and Halo games could be about to get themselves PlayStation ports as well.

Just in case you're unfamiliar with Indiana Jones and the Great Circle, it's a first-person action-adventure game developed by Wolfenstein: The New Order studio MachineGames. The game casts you as (who else?) Indiana Jones, who's investigating a characteristically complex mystery involving a cat mummy.

As you'd expect from an Indiana Jones game, you'll be visiting some pretty exotic locations throughout the course of the game, including Vatican City, Thailand, and more places besides.

Gameplay-wise, Great Circle blends scrappy melee combat, stealth, and exploration, and it's spread across a series of hub levels with plenty of distractions and sidequests to pursue. If you haven't played this one yet, you're in for a treat.

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle launches on PlayStation 5 on April 17th, and it's also currently available on PC and Xbox Series X|S. You can read our Andrew's glowing review of the game here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Assassin's Creed Shadows Debuts to Series' Highest Steam Player Count
item.content:encoded:
https://techraptor.net/gaming/news/assassins-creed-shadows-steam-player-count

Assassin's Creed Shadows, the latest game in the long-running Assassin's Creed series of stealth action-adventure games, has launched to the franchise's highest Steam player count of all time.

As spotted by the folks at Dexerto, Shadows' peak player count on Steam hit 64,825 over the weekend. At time of writing, that's still the game's peak; 43,263 players are currently enjoying Shadows, which still isn't bad considering today is a Monday.

That figure puts Assassin's Creed Shadows slightly ahead of Greek epic Assassin's Creed Odyssey, which managed to achieve a peak player count of 62,069 around the time of its release. There's not much in it, but Assassin's Creed Shadows is officially the series' biggest Steam launch.

If you're wondering how the game stacks up against other Ubisoft releases, it still can't quite hold a candle to the publisher's biggest Steam launches ever, at least not according to SteamDB's numbers.

Ubisoft's biggest Steam launch ever was the crunchy melee brawler For Honor, which achieved an impressive 225,831 peak player count in August 2018. It's followed by Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six Siege's peak of 201,933, with The Division's 114,228 (a very satisfying number) putting it in a comfortable third.

Despite the fact that Assassin's Creed Shadows can't reach those lofty heights, its success will doubtless come as a relief to Ubisoft, given that the game hasn't exactly had an easy time of it in recent months.

Announced last year, Shadows was originally set to launch in November, but was subsequently delayed to February as Ubisoft announced it would rethink some of its business practices (including releasing PC games on Steam on day one in future).

The game was then delayed again, with publisher Ubisoft closing down three of its locations and revealing its intention to pursue further cost-cutting measures after a pretty dire third-quarter performance.

It remains to be seen whether Assassin's Creed Shadows can single-handedly turn Ubisoft's fortunes around, but the game is available right now for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S. You can read our Andrew's review of the game here.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph
